awd_titl_txt: NSF-RISE: Enhancement of Research and Education Infrastructure in Nanobiomaterials, Biophysics, Biochemistry, and Environmental Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Enhancement of Research and Education Infrastructure in Nano biomaterials, Biophysics, Biochemistry, and Environmental Science and Engineering

The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Research Infrastructure for Science and Engineering (HBCU-RISE) program supports the development of research capability at Historically Black Colleges and Universities that offer doctoral degrees in science and engineering disciplines. Supported projects have a unifying research focus in one of the research areas supported by the National Science Foundation, a direct connection to the long-term plans of the host department, institutional strategic plan and mission, and plans for expanding institutional research capacity, as well as increasing the production of doctoral students, especially those underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

With National Science Foundation support, North Carolina Central University will conduct a project entitled "Enhancement of Research and Education Infrastructure in Nano biomaterials, Biophysics, Biochemistry, and Environmental Science and Engineering".  The project will elevate the current doctoral program at North Carolina Central University to a leading research and education program focused on development of advanced nanomaterials for biological applications.  The project will: a) establish additional doctoral concentrations in biophysics, biochemistry, and environmental science; b) introduce new courses in Nano biomaterials, bioinstrumentation, and interactions between nanostructures and biological materials; and c) provide financial and research support to doctoral students and research faculty involved in these new concentrations.

The project will expand the scope of the Integrated Biosciences doctoral program at North Carolina Central University through the addition of new research and educational programs focused on the intersection between nanoscale materials and biosciences. Project activities include studies on applications of nanoscale materials in the life sciences and medicine, specifically: 1) development of a new generation of biochemical sensors based on  quantum confinement and tunneling between nanostructures; 2) development of plasmonic nanostructured devices to improve selectivity and sensitivity in optical skin cancer screening and treatment; 3) design and development of novel multifunctional quantum dots for biological applications; 4) imaging of exosomes using colocalized Raman-scanning force microscopy and reduced graphene based fluorescence imaging marker materials for biological applications; 5) development of smart  hybrid nanostructures for biochemical filters, adsorption and isolation of substances and piezoelectric hybrid materials for pressure, temperature and optical sensing devices; 6) quantum calculations to improve understanding of charge transfer and interactions between nanostructures, nanostructures and biological molecules, and between diverse biological molecules; and 7) interaction of nanomaterials and biomaterials, and the impact of nanomaterial on the environment and human health.

The vision of this project is to leverage existing resources to provide new pathways for North Carolina Central University students to participate in high impact research as part of the Integrated Bioscience doctoral degree program. This project will broaden the scope of the program, making it accessible to students from a wider range of disciplines, and transform the program into a more comprehensive multidisciplinary research program that will prepare students for an increasingly competitive domestic and international research environment. This project will have a substantial impact on the research and education infrastructure at North Carolina Central University through support for faculty and student researchers and extensive curriculum development across STEM disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

por.por_cntn:
The vision of the RISE is to expand NCCU?s sole current Ph.D. program in Integrated Biosciences to include all STEM departments at NCCU. The project was successfully executed and the new interdisciplinary Ph.D. program Integrated Health and Sciences will start in Fall 2023. The first cohort of students for this program has already been accepted. 

Intellectual Merit: The RISE significantly expanded research and academic infrastructure, enhancing all NCCU STEM graduate programs and developing new research concentrations in biochemistry, environmental science, and biophysics. Seven research projects were developed, and integrated into graduate curricula. Each project is successful, as demonstrated by 67 peer-reviewed publications.

Project 1 - Development of a new generation of label-free biochemical sensors based on quantum confinement and tunneling between nanostructures. New simulation methods for nanostructures with realistic material composition, impurities, and geometry, as well as particle quasiparticle, and particle antiparticle interactions were developed.

Project 2- Development of plasmonic nanostructured devices to improve selectivity and sensitivity in optical skin cancer screening and treatment ? We investigated the growth process and the resulting structure of silver nanostructures. Dendritic silver nanostructures were produced using displacement redox reaction between AgNO3 solution and Cu foil. Potential applications of dendrites and other nanocomposites for SERS and diverse sensors, ranging from food safety to medical diagnosis, were also explored.

Project 3 - Design and development of novel multifunctional nanostructures for biological applications ? Formation of particles in multilayers, stress evolution during growth, and impact of impurities, defects, and voids, and their applications were studied. Caffeine functionalized carbon nanotubes random network-based vapor quantum resistive sensors for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) detection, which has more than an order of magnitude higher sensitivity and unique selectivity toward selective VOCs with short response times of a few seconds were developed.   

Project 4 - Imaging of exosomes using colocalized Raman-scanning force microscopy and reduced graphene-based fluorescence imaging marker materials for biological applications - Three-dimensional N-doped CNT/G hybrids with unique network structures, moderate graphitization, high specific surface area, and good mesoporosity, which make them promising materials for applications in energy storage and conversion, were synthesized. We also developed a one-step CVD synthesis technique for mesoporous 3D N-doped CNT/N-doped graphene hybrid on nickel foam.

Project 5 - Development of smart hybrid nanostructures for biochemical filters and piezoelectric hybrid materials for pressure, temperature, and optical sensing devices - To respond to the COVID pandemic, materials that have a potential to be applied as antiviral and antimicrobial filters were investigated. Our work ?Eco Solutions for Preventing Spreading of COVID 19 and Other Hazardous Bioaerosols (Antimicrobial Materials based on TiO2 and Plant Extracts)? received a bronze certificate on the ?Invention Contest for the Benefit of Humans Against Covid 19,? organized by the International Federation of Inventors? Association competition on July 6, 2020.

Project 6 - Quantum calculations to improve understanding of charge transfer and interactions between nanostructures, nanostructures and biological molecules, and between biological molecules Double QDs, double concentric quantum rings, and dot-well structures were investigated to understand and improve tunneling and entanglements between such systems. Tunneling was found to significantly depends of symmetry. The creation of piezoelectric spin trion-based that are more stable, easier to operate, and may work at higher temperatures, was also realized through these calculations.  This novel concept could significantly advance quantum computing.

Project 7 - Impact of Nanomaterial Exposure on Human Health: Protein radical formation study with anti-DMPO/Immuno-Spin-Trap method: The roles of carbon nanodots (CNDs) in the aggregation process of beta amyloid proteins in chemical and biological processes were studied. CNDs in functionalized groups were used to evaluate the extent of beta amyloid protein aggregation which was detected by anti-DMPO antibody aided proteins in the presence of hydrogen peroxides. This study helped understand the role of copper nanoparticles (CuNP) as a source of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the role of ROS on beta amyloid protein aggregation, and CNDs as a potential ROS scavenger for therapeutic application.

Broader impact: RISE Phase I made considerable contributions to the science and knowledge described above, and also addressed the current pandemic issues that are affecting society and the broader community.

The RISE program boosted NCCU?s research and academic infrastructure, creating 7 strong research programs that opened new opportunities for student and faculty research and enhanced students? training and faculty development. Fourteen new graduate courses have also been developed.

RISE I supported 28 graduate students - one INBS Ph.D. student and 27 M.S. students. All 28 supported students have graduated. Demographically, the students are 57% female and 71% Black. 12 of the students were enrolled in Environmental science, 8 in Physics, and 8 in Chemistry. All Physics and Chemistry graduates and 3 Environmental science graduates supported by RISE subsequently enrolled in Ph.D. programs, which fulfills the main mission of the program, to increase the number of minority and underrepresented Ph.D. students. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2023
Modified by: Branislav Vlahovic
